I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Poverty reduction is the overarching goal of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The 
ADB  country  strategy  for  Viet  Nam  emphasizes  sustainable  economic  growth,  poverty 
reduction,  and  inclusive  social  development.  Power  sector  investments  to  achieve  annual 
economic growth of more than 7% is a priority for the Government of Viet Nam. While large-
scale power generation projects have contributed to economic growth over the past decade, the 
benefits  from  this  growth  have  not  been  distributed  equitably.  People  displaced  by  power 
generation  projects  have  not  benefited  fully  from  the  economic  growth.  Moreover,  the 
involuntary resettlement caused by such projects often has impoverished them further. The 
Government has developed resettlement sites and livelihood programs for displaced people. 
However, due to the inadequate capacity of the authorities at the central, provincial, and district 
levels,  resettlement  and  livelihood  programs  often  have  not  been  implemented  effectively. 
People  displaced  by  hydroelectric  power  projects  often  have  been  unable  to  restore  their 
livelihoods. Livelihood restoration is often the weakest part of any resettlement plan. However, 
for hydropower projects with significant displacement and loss of livelihood, the need for well-
designed and effectively implemented livelihood programs is critical. 
2.  ADB is processing the Northern Power Transmission Expansion Sector Project (the 
Project) for approval in late 2005. The Project’s transmission lines will evacuate power from 
power plants under construction in northern Viet Nam to load centers in Hanoi, Haiphong, and 
Quang Ninh. The 2,400-megawatt Son La Hydropower Project (SLHPP)1 and 560-megawatt 
Huoi Quang Hydropower Project (HQHPP) are considered associated facilities of the proposed 
Project. SLHPP will displace about 91,000 people, while HQHPP will displace 5,000. Therefore, 
the proposed technical assistance (TA) will strengthen the institutional and technical capacity of 
national, provincial, and district authorities, as well as commune leaders, for effective planning 
and implementation of resettlement and livelihood programs for the communities affected by 
these facilities. The Resettlement Master Plan for SLHPP has been completed, and the district 
resettlement plans2 are being prepared. In June 2005, the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund 
endorsed the TA concept paper for funding.3  
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Viet Nam’s record in poverty reduction has been impressive in the past decade. The 
proportion of population living in poverty has declined from about 58% in 1993 to 29% in 2002. 
Despite this significant achievement, the reduction in poverty varies by region and ethnicity. 
About half of the ethnic minority population is poor. The northern upland region is the poorest of 
the nine regions in Viet Nam. Lai Chau is the poorest province in the northern region with a 
poverty headcount of 77.7%, while Son La ranks third at 71.4%. Insufficient investment in 
development projects, as well as poor physical and social infrastructure, has limited poverty 
reduction in the northern region. In recent years, investments have been made to improve 
physical  and  social  infrastructure,  and  to  develop  hydropower  projects  in  the  northern 
mountainous region. The Government is preparing new cycles of targeted poverty reduction 
programs. In addition, the 2001–2005 Public Investment Program has increased the public 
investment allocation to the northern mountainous and northern central region provinces to 
                                                 
1   The Government of Viet Nam is financing SLHPP and HQHPP. Construction of access roads, diversion of 
channels, and river embankment protection have started for SLHPP. The resettlement of people displaced by 
SLHPP started in 2001 on a pilot basis. The resettlement plan is being prepared for HQHPP.  
2  Eight district resettlement plans involve 270 resettlement sites. Preparation of detailed plans for each resettlement 
site will continue until 2009.

24.3% of the total, an increase from 20.3% during 1996–2000. The budget allocations to the 
Government’s targeted programs associated with poverty reduction also were increased in the 
northern regions.  
4.  Under SLHPP, relocation and resettlement of the displaced people will be completed by 
2009. Thus far, about 3,375 people have been relocated to pilot resettlement sites in three 
provinces. The recent implementation review of the Government’s resettlement plan in the pilot 
resettlement  sites4  identified  many  weaknesses  in  the  implementation  plan,  including  the 
livelihood  program.  The  findings  included:  (i)  inaccurate  assessment  for  compensation, 
(ii) inadequate disclosure and planning of income restoration and livelihood program, (iii) tension 
between relocated people and host communities, and (iv) ineffective grievance mechanism. The 
livelihoods of the relocatees, which have been disrupted by displacement, need to be restored. 
Most of the displaced people are ethnic minorities, predominantly Thai, from the provinces of 
Dien Bien, Lai Chau, and Son La. 
5.  In 1998, the Government issued a decree (22/1998/CP) to regulate compensation and 
other allowances for land structures for national and public interest. Following this decree, a 
resettlement plan for SLHPP was prepared in the pilot provinces. Based on the lessons learned 
from the pilot, the Government issued a special decision (No 459/QD-TT) in May 2004, which 
addressed gaps in the earlier decree and provided measures to maintain the standard of living 
of the affected people. The Government has approved $687 million for the resettlement and 
compensation  plans  and  livelihood  program  for  SLHPP.  Faced  now  with  the  challenge  of 
implementing  large  and  complex  resettlement  plans,  the  Government  recognizes  its  weak 
institutional and technical capacity in planning and implementing such plans and livelihood 
programs.   
 
6.  The TA Fact-Finding Mission identified specific problems with the district resettlement 
plans and livelihood activities for the affected people: (i) inadequate implementation of the 
Government’s special decision of May 2004 in the district resettlement plan and livelihood 
programs;  (ii)  lack  of  proper  land  use  planning  in  selecting  resettlement  sites;  (iii) weak 
feasibility study on the availability of adequate or suitable cultivable land for an appropriate 
upland  farming  system,  suitable  crops,  extension  and  marketing,  etc.,  for  the  livelihood 
development of the relocatees; (iv) inadequate attention to retaining the cultural and traditional 
way  of  life  and  subsistence  system  of  the  relocatees;  (v)  more  emphasis  on  building 
infrastructure in the resettlement sites than on preparing livelihood programs for the relocatees; 
(vi) inadequate  consultation  with  the  affected  people  (relocatees  and  host  communities) 
regarding relocation, land acquisition, compensation, and retention of traditional way of living in 
the resettlement sites; (vii) no specific grievance process established to address resettlement 
issues at the commune and district level for the affected people; and (viii) district resettlement 
and  compensation  management  committees  (DRCMC)  in  most  cases  do  not  include 
representatives  from  the  District  Agriculture  and  Rural    Development  Division  and  Natural 
Resource  Management  Division.  Rather,  most  members  of  the  committees  are  from  the 
infrastructure division. In two districts, resettlement plans are linked to the urban development 
plan of the districts, which could complicate further the resettlement and livelihood programs of 
SLHPP. Further, the DRCMC does not have a representative from the Committee for Ethnic 
Minorities in Mountainous Area. Overall, the provincial resettlement steering committees and the 
DRCMCs  lack  the  institutional  and  technical  expertise  to  plan  and  implement  effectively 
resettlement and livelihood programs. Domestic consulting firms prepared the detailed district 
                                                 
4  Viet Nam Son LA Hydropower Project: Resettlement Due Diligence Report, MKID/MKRD, May 2005.

3
plans, because of DRCMC’s weak technical expertise. As such, the quality of the district plans 
cannot be ensured. 
 
7.  The  ethnic  minority  communities  in  the  affected  areas  depend  mainly  on  wetland 
agriculture. Since  the  proposed  resettlement  sites  are in  the  upland, a  change in  farming 
systems from wetland agriculture to upland agriculture will be needed. Selection of resettlement 
sites  for  upland  farming  and  development  of  livelihood  program  will  require  (i)  significant 
technical skills of national and local authorities in land use planning; (ii) selection of farmland for 
upland agriculture; (iii) selection of suitable crops; (iv) management and sustainable use of 
natural  resources;  and  (v)  assessment  of  capital  requirements  for  production,  agriculture 
extension services, marketing facilities, etc. For the affected people downstream, an income 
restoration  program  will  require  technical  expertise  in  community-based  aquaculture 
development. A comprehensive review is needed of the Master Resettlement Plan, as well as 
the district resettlement plans and livelihood programs. The aim is to (i) assess the selection of 
resettlement sites for appropriate livelihood development programs for the affected people; 
(ii) identify the institutional and technical capacity required at the national, provincial, district, 
and commune level for developing an effective resettlement plan and livelihood program; and (iii) 
identify the gaps between Special Decision No 459/QDT and the district resettlement plans. 
 
8.  In 2001, ADB approved a TA grant5 to prepare a new decree on compensation and 
rehabilitation. The proposed TA will complement capacity building under TA 3727. However, 
while the proposed TA on SLHPP will be completed within two years, the resettlement and 
livelihood  program  of  SLHPP  will  continue  until  2009.  The  capacity  development  training 
program of this TA for national, provincial, and district authorities from Son La, Dien Bien, and 
Lai Chao provinces, as well as commune leaders, will increase their capacity in formulating and 
implementing the resettlement plans and livelihood programs for SLHPP and HQHPP. The 
outputs of the TA will be used for the Project in the northern provinces, and for the proposed 
ADB-supported Son Bung 4 Hydropower Project in Quang Nam Province in Central Viet Nam. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The long-term impact of the TA will be sustainable livelihood development programs for 
the affected people of SLHPP and HQHPP. The outcome of the TA will be increased capacity of 
the national, provincial, and district resettlement authorities, as well as grassroots stakeholders, 
for  developing  appropriate  livelihood  programs  for  the  affected  people,  including  ethnic 
minorities.  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will (i) review the existing livelihood  system and proposed livelihood programs of 
the  district  resettlement  plan  for  the  affected  people  (relocatees  and  host  communities); 
(ii) review  the  development  of  a  framework  and  operational  guideline  for  preparation  of 
livelihood programs relevant to different ethnic groups, with specific focus on ethnic minorities, 
women, and other vulnerable groups; (iii) review the Master Resettlement Plan and district 
resettlement  plans  for  the  affected  people,  and  develop  a  comprehensive  framework  and 
operational guidelines for improving the district plans for SLHPP and HQHPP; (iv) develop 
                                                 
5 ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for Enhancing the Resettlement, Legal 
Framework and Institutional Capacity. Manila (TA 3727-VIE).

4   
guidelines for the selection of appropriate resettlement sites for improving the livelihood system 
of  the  affected  people;  (v) assess  the  institutional  capacity  and  technical  expertise  of  the 
national, provincial, and district authorities, as well as the leaders of communes and mass 
organizations,  in  formulating,  implementing,  and  monitoring  resettlement  and  sustainable 
livelihood  programs  for  resettled  people;  (vi)  develop  capacity  building  training  modules; 
(vii) undertake the training of trainers (TOT) for the relevant resource people from national, 
provincial, and district authorities,6 as well as men and women leaders of the communes and 
mass organizations; (viii) prepare a master training plan for continuation of the training for the 
relevant members of the national, provincial, and district resettlement committees, as well as 
men and women leaders of the communes and mass organizations; (ix) review the commune-
level  consultation  and  monitoring  system  for  planning  and  implementing  resettlement  and 
livelihood programs, and recommend mechanisms for improved consultation and monitoring in 
line  with  Decree  79  (Grassroots  Democracy)  and  Decree  80  (Regulation  for  Participatory 
Investment  Supervision);  (ix)  initiate  dialogue  with  the  provincial  and  district  authorities  on 
establishing a separate grievance system for resettlement; (x) recommend an effective system 
for monitoring  resettlement activities and livelihood programs within the Ministry of Agriculture 
and  Rural  Development  (MARD),  and  provincial  and  district  resettlement  committees;  and 
(xi) develop monitoring indicators, disaggregated by ethic groups and gender, to assess the 
implementation of resettlement activities, income restoration, and livelihood programs. 
 
11.  The review of Master Resettlement Plan and the district resettlement plans with the 
relevant national, provincial, district, and commune leaders from the affected areas will help to 
formulate  an  appropriate  framework  and  operational  guidelines  for  improving  the  existing 
resettlement  plans  and  livelihood  programs  of  Son  La.  This  process  also  will  help  in  the 
preparation of effective resettlement plans and livelihood programs for the subsequent years of 
SLHPP  and  HQHPP.  The  capacity  building  training  program  will  focus  on  preparation  of 
resettlement and livelihood programs following the training needs assessment and operational 
guidelines prepared under the TA. The training program will focus on (i) effective consultations 
at  the  village  and  commune  levels  for  assessment  of  inventory  loss,  land  acquisition,  
compensation,  etc.,  relevant  to  ethnic  groups  and  gender;  (ii)  grassroots-level    planning, 
implementation, and monitoring of resettlement activities and livelihood programs using the 
framework of  Decree 79 and Decree 80; (iii) selection of resettlement sites based on land use 
planning for an appropriate farming system and sustainable income generation from farm and 
off-farm activities; (iv) planning of crops and extension services for an upland farming system; (v) 
management of natural resources for sustainable use and income; (vi)  planning of farm and off-
farm activities for immediate and long-term income generation and capital requirements, and 
extension and marketing facilities, etc.; (vii) downstream aquaculture planning; (viii) selection of 
resettlement sites for suitable physical and social infrastructure; (ix) planning and coordination 
between livelihood programs in the resettlement sites and the Government’s rural development 
and  poverty  reduction  programs;  (x)  development  of  an  appropriate  grievance  process  for 
addressing resettlement issues; (xi) monitoring system for resettlement and livelihood activities 
at  the  national,  provincial,  district,  and  commune  levels;  and  (xii)  monitoring  indicators 
disaggregated by ethnic groups and gender. The increased capacity of the authorities at the 
national,  province,  and  district  levels  will  facilitate  implementation  of  Special  Decision  No 
459/QD-TT as an effective resettlement and livelihood plan relevant to the livelihood system of 
ethnic groups in the mountainous region.  
                                                 
6  TOT for selected staff from Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, National Institute for Agricultural Plan 
and Projection, Son La Power Project Management Board, Electricity of Viet Nam, and Power Engineering 
Consulting Company of EVN; provincial and district resettlement steering committees; DRCMCs, and selected 
leaders of district women’s union, communes, and mass organizations.

C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The estimated cost of the TA is $1,250,000 equivalent, comprising $609,000 in foreign 
exchange cost and $641,000 equivalent of local currency cost. ADB will provide a grant of 
$1,000,000 from the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund, covering the entire foreign exchange 
cost and $391,000 equivalent of local currency cost. The grant will be used for financing 
international  and  domestic  consultants,  including  (i)  preparation  of  guidelines  and  training 
modules; and (ii) TOT and training of the national, provincial, and district authorities, as well as 
commune leaders. The Government of Viet Nam will provide $250,000 equivalent for the TA, 
primarily through in-kind contributions to cover accommodations, venue of training, counterpart 
support, transport and monitoring of the training, and TA implementation. ADB will administer 
the TA. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  MARD will be the Executing Agency of the TA, facilitating implementation of the training 
program and monitoring TA activities. A national project director from MARD will head the 
project office. Within MARD, a steering committee will be formed comprising representatives 
from  national  resettlement  committees,  Ministry  of  Finance,  Electricity  of  Viet  Nam,  and 
chairpersons of three provincial steering committees on resettlement and compensation. The 
steering committee, which will play an advisory role, will meet every 6 months to review the 
progress of the TA.    
 
14.  International and domestic consultants will implement the TA. The TA will require 72 
person-months of consulting services, including 24 person-months of international consultants 
and 48 person-months of domestic consultants. The consultants will be recruited individually in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The terms of reference of the 
consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
15.  The TA, which will be implemented over 2 years, is expected to start in January 2006 
and be completed in December 2007. The first 2 months will be used to select the consultants 
and prepare the start of the TA. The next month will focus on (i) review of district plans; (ii) visits 
to proposed resettlement sites; (iii) consultations with the government authorities, commune 
leaders,  and  affected  people;  and  (iv)  assessment  of  training  needs.  The  preparation  of 
guidelines for the resettlement plans and livelihood programs, and development of training 
modules and TOT program for the relevant government authorities, commune leaders, and 
mass organizations, will be completed by October 2006. Training of the national, provincial, and 
district authorities, as well as leaders of communes and mass organizations, will continue until 
October 2007. The final report of the TA will be completed by December 2007.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation 
Fund, for Strengthening Institutional Capacity of Local Stakeholders for Implementation of Son 
La Livelihood and Resettlement Plan, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Projection (NIAPP), Son La Power Project Management Board, Electricity of Viet Nam (EVN), Power Engineering 
Consulting Company (PECC) of EVN, provincial steering committees on resettlement and compensation, district 
resettlement compensation and management committees (DRCMC), selected leaders of district Women’s Union, and 
men and women leaders of the affected communes and mass organizations. The master training plan will include 
approximately 1,080 trainees from 111 communes from eight project districts in three provinces: (i) Son La, (ii) Dien 
Bien, and (iii) Lai Chao. The trainees will be selected from national authorities (MARD, NIAPP, EVN, and PECC); 
provincial  and  district  resettlement  steering  committees;  provincial  resettlement  and  compensation  committee; 
DRCMCs, leaders of the district Women’s Union, and men and women leaders of communes and mass organizations. 
    Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

10   Appendix 3 
 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants (24 person-months) 
1.  Four international consultants will be recruited individually for 24 person-months. The 
consultants will work with Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) to implement 
the Technical Assistance (TA). Consulting services will be required in the following areas: 
(i) resettlement specialist, (ii) land use planner, (iii) upland farming specialist, and (iv) natural 
resource management and fishery specialist. The consultants should have experience working 
in the Greater Mekong Subregion, as well substantial experience in their respective areas. The 
responsibilities of the international consultants are described in paras. 2–5: 
 
1.  Resettlement Specialist and Team Coordinator (6 person-months) 
 
2.  The resettlement specialist must have substantive experience preparing resettlement 
plans for hydropower projects, and implementing resettlement plans in the mountainous region 
for  ethnic  minority  groups.  The  resettlement  specialist  should  have  experience  in  rural 
development and livelihood development programs in the mountainous region. In coordination 
with the international and domestic consultants, the resettlement specialist will: 
(i)  Desk and filed review of Master Resettlement Plan and district resettlement plans 
and  livelihood  activities  with  MARD,  National  Institute  for  Agricultural  Plan  and 
Projection  (NIAPP),  Son  La  Power  Management  Board,  provincial  resettlement 
steering committees, provincial resettlement and compensation committees, district 
resettlement compensation management committees (DRCMC), men and women 
leaders from the affected commune and mass organizations. 
(ii)  Prepare,  in  cooperation  with  the  consultant  team  and  relevant  government 
authorities,  a  comprehensive  framework  and  operational  guidelines  for  district 
resettlement plans (covering future resettlement sites), which incorporate livelihood 
programs relevant to the resettlement sites and appropriate for the ethnic groups and 
gender of the relocatees. 
(iii)  Prepare  recommendations  for  improving  the  resettlement  sites  of  the  district 
resettlement plans that are being implemented.  
(iv)  Conduct  a  training  needs  assessment,  in  coordination  with  the  consultants,  for 
MARD, NIAPP, Son La Power Management Board, provincial resettlement steering 
committees, provincial resettlement and compensation committees, DRCMCs, and 
men and women leaders from the affected communes and mass organizations; and 
prepare training modules (para. 11 of main report) and Master Training Plan for 
approximate 1,080 trainees. 
(v)  Conduct Training of Trainer (TOT) (for approximately 330 trainees) on the modules 
for formulating resettlement and livelihood programs related to Son La Hydropower 
Project for the relevant resource people from MARD, NIAPP, Son La  Power Project 
Management Board, Electricity of Viet Nam (EVN), Power Engineering Consulting 
Company  of  EVN,  provincial  and  district  steering  committees  for  resettlement, 
DRCMCs, provincial and district Women’s Union, and men and women leaders of 
the communes and mass organizations from the affected communes.  
(vi)  Facilitate links between the Government’s rural development program and poverty 
program with the livelihood program in the resettlement sites.  
(vii)  Review the consultation system for planning and implementation of resettlement and 
livelihood  programs,  and  recommend  mechanisms  to  improve  the  consultation

Appendix 3   11 
process in line with Decree 79 (Grassroots Democracy) and Decree 80 (Regulation 
for Participatory Investment Supervision).  
(viii)  Initiate dialogue with the provincial and district authorities on establishing a separate 
grievance system for resettlement.  
(ix)  Recommend an effective system for monitoring resettlement activities and livelihood 
programs  within  MARD,  provincial  steering  committees  for  resettlement,  and 
DRCMCs.  
(x)  Recommend  mechanisms  for  a  grassroots-level  monitoring  system  in  line  with 
Decree 79 and Decree 80. 
(xi)  Disaggregate  monitoring  indicators  by  ethic  groups  and  gender  to  assess  the 
implementation of resettlement activities, income restoration, and livelihood program. 
(xii)  Prepare report on TA activities.  
 
  2.  Land Use Planner (6 person-months)  
 
3.  The land use planner should have substantive experience in land use planning in the 
mountainous region for residential settlement and farming system development. The consultant, 
who will coordinate with the resettlement specialist, will:  
(i)  Desk and filed review of Master Resettlement Plan and district resettlement plans 
and livelihood activities with MARD, NIAPP, Son La Power Management Board, 
provincial resettlement steering committees, DRCMCs, and men and women leaders 
from the affected communes and mass organizations.   
(ii)  Prepare,  in  cooperation  with  the  consultant  team  and  relevant  government 
authorities,  an  operational  guideline  on  land  use  planning  for  selection  of 
resettlement sites; incorporate the guidelines in the district resettlement plans.  
(iii)  Conduct training needs assessment, and based on this assessment and operational 
guidelines  (para.  11  of  main  report),  prepare  training  modules  for  selection  of 
resettlement sites appropriate for upland farming system and sustainable income 
generation  from  land,  natural  resources,  and  suitable  physical  and  social 
infrastructure.  
(iv)  Conduct TOT on the guidelines for land use planning for the relevant resource 
people  from  MARD,  NIAPP,  Son  La  Power  Project  Management  Board,  EVN, 
provincial and district steering committees for resettlement, DRCMCs, and leaders of 
the district Women’s Union and affected communes and mass organizations.  
(v)  Prepare simple training module on land use planning for commune-level training.  
(vi)  Prepare monitoring indicators on resettlement site selection.  
(vii)  Prepare report on TA activities.  
 
3.  Upland Farming System Specialist (6 person-months) 
 
4.  The upland farming system specialist should have substantive experience in integrated 
farming in the upland. The consultant, who will coordinate with the resettlement specialist, will: 
(i)  Desk and file review of Master Resettlement Plan and district resettlement  plans and 
livelihood  activities  with  MARD,  NIAPP,  Son  La  Power  Management  Board, 
provincial resettlement steering committees, DRCMCs, leaders of the provincial and 
district Women’s Union, and men and women leaders from the affected communes 
and mass organizations. 
(ii)  Prepare,  in  cooperation  with  the  consultant  team  and  relevant  government 
authorities,  an  operational  guideline  for  livelihood  development  program  which 
incorporates  planning  of  upland  farming  system,  extension  knowledge  on  fast-

12   Appendix 3 
 
 
 
growing field crops and tree crops, and crops and trees that will provide long-term 
sustainable income; incorporate the guideline in the district resettlement plans. 
(iii)  Prepare training modules on upland integrated farming system, including tree crops 
and livestock.  
(iv)  Conduct TOT on upland farming system for the resource people from MARD, NIAPP, 
provincial and district steering committees for resettlement, DRCMCs, and men and 
women leaders of the communes and mass organizations.  
(v)  Develop a simple handbook on upland farming system, farming plan, and extension 
information  (for  men  and  women  farmers),  including  capital  requirements  for 
production and marketing, etc.  
(vi)  Facilitate links between the Government’s rural development program and poverty 
program and the livelihood program in the resettlement sites.  
(vii)  Develop gender-based monitoring indicators on farm production and income.  
(viii)  Prepare report on TA activities. 
 
4.  Natural Resource Management and Fishery Specialist (6 person-months) 
 
5.  The natural resource management specialist should have substantive experience in 
natural resource management and fisheries. In coordination with international and domestic 
consultants, the specialist will:  
(i)  Desk and filed review of Master Resettlement Plan and district resettlement plans and 
livelihood activities with MARD, NIAPP, Son La Power Management Board, provincial 
resettlement steering committees, DRCMCs, district Women’s Union, and men and 
women leaders from the affected communes and mass organizations. 
(ii)  Prepare, in cooperation with the consultant team and relevant government authorities, 
an operational guideline on natural resource management and sustainable use of 
forest resource for the relocatees in the upland; incorporate the guidelines in the 
district resettlement plan for livelihood program development   
(iii)  Prepare  a  community-based  aquaculture  plan  and  training  plan  for  the  relevant 
provincial and district authorities from the fisheries, as well as the affected people 
downstream. 
(iv)  Prepare training modules on sustainable use and management of natural resource in 
the resettlement sites in the upland and aquaculture downstream. 
(v)  Conduct TOT for the relevant government authorities, as well as men and women 
leaders of the commune and the mass organizations, on sustainable use of natural 
resources, planning and management of aquaculture and extension activities. 
(vi)  Coordinate with the Danish International Aid Agency’s community-based aquaculture 
program downstream of Son La in planning of aquaculture activities;  
(vii)  Establish a system for monitoring aquaculture activities. 
(viii)  Prepare report on TA activities.   
 
B.  Domestic Consultants (48 person-months)  
 
6.  Six  domestic  consultants  will  be  recruited  individually  for  48  person-months.  The 
domestic consultants will work with the international consultants and MARD to implement the 
TA. Consulting services will be required in the following areas: (i) resettlement specialist and 
rural  development  specialist  (24  person-months),  (ii)  land  use  planer  (5  person-months), 
(iii) upland farming specialist (6 person-months), (iv) rural off-farm income-generating specialist 
(4  person-months);  (v)  social  development  and  gender  specialist  (5  person-months),  and 
(vi) ethnic minority specialist (4 person-months).

Appendix 3   13 
 
7.  The domestic consultants are to assist the international consultants with (i) reviewing the 
Master  Resettlement  Plan  and  district  resettlement  plans,  (ii)  preparing  the  guidelines  for 
formulating the resettlement plan and livelihood programs (farm and off-farm activities) for the 
new district resettlement sites, and (iii) improving the existing sites in the district plans. With the 
international consultants, the domestic consultants will prepare training modules and a training 
plan,  conduct  TOT,  and  develop  monitoring  indicators.  The  social  development/gender 
specialist  and  ethnic  minority  specialist  will  provide  social,  cultural,  gender,  and  ethnic 
dimensions  to  the  guidelines  and  training  modules.  These  specialists  also  will  implement 
Decree 79 and Decree 80. This entails developing training modules and a training program for 
local consultation on formulating and implementing resettlement plans, livelihood programs, and 
community-level monitoring. The resettlement and rural development specialist will monitor the 
training program throughout TA implementation.
